Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Electron-Beam Lithography System for Nanofabrication and Processing

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
MRI: Acquisition of Electron-Beam Lithography System for Nanofabrication and Processing

Research Objectives and Approaches: The objective of this research is to acquire a state-of-the-art electron-beam lithography (EBL) system critical for fabrication and investigation of nano-structures. The approach is to use the EBL system to define nanoscale features in cutting-edge interdisciplinary research in nano-photonics, electronics and sensing. The instrument will be an integral part of the unique Nano-Fabrication and Processing (NF&P) facility at the University of Arizona for the exploration of nano-structured components and systems.

Intellectual Merit: The EBL system will be essential in realizing the state-of-the-art research in silicon photonics and integration of optics with electronics and software on silicon chips. The feature sizes for the silicon photonic chips are reaching sub-50 nm that would be reliably supported by the EBL system. This research would also be instrumental in the NSF Engineering Research Center on Integrated Access Networks (CIAN) and will be useful to researchers from other partner universities within CIAN. Furthermore, the requested system will enable a wide range of novel opportunities in nano-scale R&D, providing a unique capability especially for the young faculty and students with innovative thinking.

Broader Impacts: Advances in nano-technology is revolutionizing the fields of information technology, alternative energy, environmental sciences, healthcare, and homeland security. The EBL will be an essential tool in the education and training of students in nano-science and technology. Also, faculty and researchers associated with the minority serving schools that are partnered with CIAN ERC including Norfolk State University and Tuskegee University will be able to take advantage of this facility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the MRI grant, the University of Arizona acquired an Elionix ELS-7000 electron beam lithography (EBL) system which was installed at eh College of Optical Sciences cleanroom in the spring of 2013. The ability to create features in the range of 10-50 nm is a fundamental requirement state of the art nano-technology research. The installed system has been proven to meet the resolution requirements of better than 10 nm. Specifically, the system is capable of operating under different accelerating voltages, field sizes and beam currents. The chart below gives the minimum achievable spot size under various operating conditions.

Vacc

Min Spot Size

Max Field Size

Beam Current Range

100kV

1.8nm

600um

10pA - 20nA

75kV

2.2nm

1200um

10pA - 5nA

50kV

2.8nm

1200um

10pA - 1nA

25kV

4nm

2400um

10pA - 0.5nA

The first results of experiments and testing of the system as demonstrated the capabilities for high resolution writing of patterns as small as 8 nm. In fact, since the system has been installed, several groups at the University have benefited from the systems capabilities. Various research groups have fabricated patterns with a linewidth in the 10-50 nm with large field sizes on the order of 1200 um. Some of the research includes: nano-antenna’s, metallic nano-wires, plasmonic EO modulators, and the fabrication of MMI devices. The system is a critical tool in nanotechnology research and education at the University of Arizona and within the State of Arizona. The acquisition of the EBL system creates major opportunities in the interdisciplinary research activities within the three colleges at the University.


Last Modified: 05/31/2015
Modified by: Chris Hessenius
